comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Golly she was a VERY OLD ship - launched 1814, butchered in the late 19th century, and eventually scrapped in 1926 - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Nelson_(1814) The Figurehead is in the Australian National Maritime Museum - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Lord_Nelson_01.jpg

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Right you are! Here is a link to the figurehead over on eMuseum.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Oh My Giddy Aunt! Just identified another contemporary (c.1895) photo of HMVS NELSON (1814) from that figurehead. From the mysterious Phillips Collection (PhM), as a hulk ... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3093478429/]mega-zoomify from.ph/381230

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Colonial Sugar Refining Co. works at Pyrmont (built 1877) and the original (not 1903) Glebe Island Bridge are marked on this interactive 1895 map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=... .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1929 fuller history of the ship - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/69519134 . From this it seems she was in Sydney from 1901-1908 near Cremorne.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That Trove article is a wealth of info and detail!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Another sighting of the HMVS NELSON ?? -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/5498377638/]

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Brilliant work, thanks beachcomberaustralia! i don't see any sign of Callan Park Hospital behind the CSR works, so I'd guess that the Maritime Museum photo is before 1885.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman] No Don, this is the wrong bay for Callan Park - this pic is Johnstone's Bay off Pyrmont (see map link above),  not Iron Cove.  Sydney harbour is <u>so</u> muddling! 

I think the poor old hulk was pushed around Sydney like flotsam between 1901-08.  In Don's photo she has lost the topmast since the other two.  I expect that the NELSON will turn up in the background of other photos now we know what we are looking at.

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Duhhh, would have helped if I had read the comments and put the brain in gear before starting to type!!!! Sorry!

comment.author: 89563874@N07
comment._content:
Inscription says Port Jackson July 1887.  Close up of top picture shows them getting ready for tennis or having already played.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle/9505986217/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] Thanks Ted - great pics. Here's an 1887 article on HMS NELSON & Chief Admiral Fairfax. The vessel 'returned to Farm Cove' in August from a visit to Fiji & the New Hebrides.
